definition: to pinch (with one's fingers)/to knead/to make up
to make/to build/to manufacture/to invent/to fabricate/to go to/party (in a lawsuit or legal agreement)/crop/classifier for crops

sentences.english: Francis is accused of having helped him to concoct a false alibi.
sentences.chinese: 弗朗西斯因帮助他捏造不在犯罪现场的证据而被起诉。

sentences.english: And btw, all the Chinese Pollutionfigures are fudged.
sentences.chinese: 顺便提一句，所有有关中国污染的诗句都是捏造的。

sentences.english: He faked up the whole thing-none of it was true.
sentences.chinese: 他捏造了全部事情，没有一点是真的。

sentences.english: The teachers taught the children how to falsify facts for the reporters.
sentences.chinese: 老师们甚至还教孩子们怎么去捏造事实，应付记者。

sentences.english: False rumors have soiled the family name.
sentences.chinese: 捏造的谣言辱没了家声。
该政府称录像是“捏造”的。

sentences.english: Because really, how long can any person fake it and maintain a facade?
sentences.chinese: 因为，确实地，一个人能捏造并保持一个假象多久呢？

sentences.english: Currency movements switch demand between countries; they do not create it.
sentences.chinese: 货币流动需要在国家之间进行切换，而不能凭空捏造。

sentences.english: They were railroaded to prison by their enemies.
sentences.chinese: 他们被敌人捏造罪名强行投入监狱。

sentences.english: I'd rather be three months ill, than hear you frame a deliberate lie.'
sentences.chinese: 我宁可病三个月，也不愿听你编一套故意捏造的瞎话。

sentences.english: This will reduce the temptation to fudge on your boundaries.
sentences.chinese: 这将减少你在捏造分界线的机会。

sentences.english: In the fall of 1943 false and malicious gossip was circulating.
sentences.chinese: 在一九四三年秋季，流传著一种捏造和恶意的闲谈。

sentences.english: I know just how to fake it .
Reach " barefaced affront other is concoctive perhaps the fact is calumniatory other " wait for case.
sentences.chinese: 及“公然侮辱他人或者捏造事实诽谤他人”等情形。

definition: to compile/to draw up/to fabricate/to invent/to concoct/to make up/to cook up
to start rumours and create trouble
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
variant of 誣衊|诬蔑[wu1 mie4]
variant of 污衊|污蔑[wu1 mie4]
to discredit/to defame/to smear sb's name/to bring shame upon (oneself or one's family etc)/to blacken (e.g. commando's face for camouflage)/to black out or obliterate (e.g. censored words)
to concoct a cock-and-bull story (idiom)/to make things up
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
